dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The field is in a state of disrepair, some plants yellowe and rotting, others growing outside of the weathered wood fence that surrounds the field. Some patterns are still apparent, indicating that at one time the corn was plante rows. A wood house rests behind the field, its shutters swaying silently in the breeze. The paint has peeled off the hous long ago, if it was ever there, and the outside of the ho has been bleached by the sun. In the field, a scarecrow stands, bound to a wooden cross with twine. This scarecrow is the only thing in the field that looks as if it may have been tended to recently, its dark suit unfaded and neat. At the base of the scarecrow’s cross, ants scurry up and the wooden pole, teeming over each other

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The year is 1862, the second year of the American civil w The bank, a large, plain building, rests in the center of small southern town, on the side of a wide dirt road. A g of six Confederate soldiers, in gray uniforms, ride down street on well-groomed horses, towards the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four of the six soldiers enter the bank, the middle two e carrying two bags. The bank’s counter has two barred wind one of which is already occupied by an attractive young w in an expensive dress, who is speaking intently with the teller, a young, awkward man. The four soldiers cross to other window. The old male teller at this window looks at the soldiers surprised, as two of them set their bags heavily on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: TALL SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Your manager in? The elderly teller nods. TALL SOLDIER (CONT’D) Go get him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soldiers wait, looking around the bank, as the teller hurries away behind the window. Aside from themselves and woman at the other window, there are no other customers i the bank. A rough-looking man stands next to the door, a large four-chamber revolver stuck prominently into his be obviously representing security. A door in the wall rattles and a middle-aged man steps ou wearing spectacles. He moves towards the soldiers solicitously, the old teller following him. The tall sold looks at the man levelly. TALL SOLDIER (CONT’D) You MacCready?

dialogues.speaker: MACCREADY
dialogues.text: Yes, I am. Fred MacCready’s my name. How may I help you gentlemen?

dialogues.speaker: TALL SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Corporal Williams said you might have a place where we could put this. He indicates the bags.

dialogues.speaker: MACCREADY
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Did the corporal give you any message for me? The tall soldier takes a folded piece of paper from his pocket and hands it to MacCready. MacCready unfolds the p and nervously looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two other Confederate soldiers are standing outside t bank, looking around, while one of them feeds the horses. other soldier, blonde and covered with dust, standing a f feet away, looks down the dirt street. A few hundred feet away, four more Confederate soldiers a riding horses towards them, moving slowly. A black man le one of their horses, walking on foot. A medium-sized dog trots alongside him. The blonde soldier, seeing this, turns to his companion.

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Hey, look at that. The other soldier looks up from his task, squinting, revealing bad teeth. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BUCKTOOTH SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Who the hell are they?

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE SOLDIER
dialogues.text: I don’t know. The blonde soldier turns and faces the oncoming gray soldiers, waving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacCready faces the four soldiers inside the bank, cheerf pocketing the note.

dialogues.speaker: MACCREADY
dialogues.text: Well, it looks like everything’s in order, then. You understand my having to check. Security these days. The tall soldier looks at him, unsmiling.

dialogues.speaker: TALL SOLDIER
dialogues.text: You got a safe we should be taking this to?

dialogues.speaker: MACCREADY
dialogues.text: The best in the state... But first, I’1l need you to sign for this.

dialogues.speaker: TALL SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MACCREADY
dialogues.text: (faltering) Well... I mean, you will want a receipt for it, won’t you?

dialogues.speaker: TALL SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Oh. Yeah, sure. MacCready looks at the elderly teller, gesturing towards counter. The teller shuffles away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four soldiers on horseback approach the two soldiers outside the bank. The man in front, with his horse being by the black man, has dark hair and eyes and is chewing tobacco. This is WILLIAM. The black man, TODD, is slender, and watches the two soldiers, unblinking. The blonde soldier addresses Willia somewhat hesitantly. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Where you men in from? William slides off his horse, landing on his feet, and ti the horse’s reins to a wooden post in front of the bank. three men on horseback behind him do the same. One of these men is SAM, who looks like a younger version William and is also chewing tobacco. The other two are JOSEPH, a large, wide-shouldered man, and CLYDE, a smalle wiry, rugged man. The four move towards the two soldiers friendly.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Camp just over that way, about two miles east, near the swamps.

dialogues.speaker: BUCKTOOTH SOLDIER
dialogues.text: (somewhat suspiciously) Who’s your lieutenant over there?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Ain’t got no lieutenant right now. Cap’ain Louison’s around, though. The two soldiers relax slightly at this response. William taps Todd on the shoulder, roughly.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go help the men with their horses, boy. Todd shoots him a quick look, then walks over to the two soldiers’ horses, head bowed. The bucktooth soldier hands the feed bag.

dialogues.speaker: BUCKTOOTH SOLDIER
dialogues.text: What’re you doing here in town?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (gestures) Got some business at the bank.

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Well, you’re gonna have to wait a few minutes. William squints up at the sun.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Nope. Can’t wait. William begins moving towards the bank. Sam, Joseph and C follow. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE SOLDIER
dialogues.text: (steps forward, nervous) No, I mean, you really gotta. We can’t let anyone in there right now. It’ll just be a few minutes, though. The four men do not pause, continuing towards the door to bank. The blonde soldier and the bucktooth soldier exchan quick glances, then the blonde soldier draws his rifle, cocking the hammer and leveling it at the William.

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE SOLDIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now, stop right- He is cut off as the blade of a thick knife enters his ne Todd spins, tugging the knife out of the blonde soldier’s throat, releasing a spout of blood, and stabs the bucktoo soldier in the chest before the bucktooth soldier can rea Todd looks up at William, stooping over the body of the bucktooth soldier. William nods, and Todd leans over and picks up the blonde soldier’s rifle, then begins untying horses. William opens the doors to the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacCready and one of the other soldiers are carrying the bags behind the counter when William and his men burst in the bank, drawing guns. Joseph grabs the security guard as the man reaches for hi revolver. They struggle for a moment, then Joseph breaks guard’s neck, dropping him to the floor, and pulls out a William aims his pistols at the men with the bags.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Hold it there. MacCready and the soldiers freeze. The tall soldier pulls rifle from a holster at his bag, swinging it towards Will Sam leans over, aiming his pistol, and shoots the tall soldier in the head. William empties his guns, hitting both MacCready and the other soldier, as Clyde and Joseph shoot the other two soldiers. The elderly teller, the young teller and the girl are sti standing, staring. Slowly, the younger teller reaches und the counter. The girl, standing across from him, sees thi She flips a straight razor out of her sleeve, leans forwa and cuts the teller’s throat. The young teller falls back spraying the girl with blood. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soldier who was moving the bags with MacCready is twitching on the ground, gasping, still alive. William an Clyde both notice this. Clyde begins pouring gun powder f a paper packet into the barrel of his pistol, but William sighs, steps forward, and takes out a hunting knife. He w over to the soldier and stabs him in the chest William stands up, surveying the room. His eyes meet the girl’s and he smiles.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, there. William moves over to the girl, ANNABELLE, and they kiss. wipes her razor clean on her dress, then tucks it back in her sleeve. The young teller lies still on the opposite s of the counter.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Quick work, Annabelle. You cut him? I didn’t even see it.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Alright, anyone else still alive in here? Clyde gestures at the elderly teller, who is backed away them in a corner, trembling and pale.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Him, sort of. William begins loading one of his pistols.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Well, kill him. Clyde aims his pistol at the elderly teller.

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY TELLER
dialogues.text: No, please don’t... The teller chokes, then clutches at his chest. His eyes r up into his head and he falls to his knees, then to the floor, his eyes closing. The teller lies still on the flo Clyde looks at William, frowning, then turns back towards elderly teller’s prone body and shoots him.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Just in case. Joseph and Sam are holding the four bags. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Those heavy, Joseph? Joseph nods, excited.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well then, let’s get the hell out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Todd is standing in front of the bank with his gun drawn, other hand holding all six of the soldiers’ horses by the reins. He warily looks up and down the street. The dog st next to Todd, indifferent People are watching Todd, and the bank, but nobody is doi anything. Most people have run into buildings to hide, bu the rest are watching Todd, unnaturally. He returns their gaze, looking from face to face. William, Annabelle, Clyde, Joseph and Sam come running ou the bank. Todd turns to them, lifting the dog up into a saddlebag on one of the horses.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: About fucking time. They each leap up onto a horse, grabbing the reins and ta their horses off down the street at a gallop. Ahead of th three men in Confederate uniforms run out of a grocery st aiming rifles.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: Oh, hell. Clyde, William and Todd begin shooting at the soldiers as they ride past. One of the soldiers is hit, falling back Behind him, a woman screams. Next to her, a very small bo lying on the ground, blood all over his face and neck. Everything grows still for a moment as William sees this. William flinches and looks away from the boy as the six thunder past the grocery store. Then they are down the st and gone, as the two remaining soldiers run around the st corner, after their horses. The woman kneels over the sma boy in the street, weeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The six ride their horses quickly, Sam next to William. T dog is riding in Sam’s saddlebag, and Sam feeds it a piec dried beef. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Good boy, Dog. (to William) How many do you think’1l be after us?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Not many, right away, and those’d be the only that could catch up in time to find us. William looks over at Sam, who has a dark circle of blood growing on his shoulder, over a hole in the shirt.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’re hit. Sam looks where William is looking, down at his own shoul

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Just in the shoulder. I don’t think it’s real bad, I can move it around okay, it ain’t near the bone or nothing. We’1ll get it out later. William looks like he wants to say more, but turns away a urges his horse on faster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The six carefully work their way through a dim, wooded ar carefully guiding their horses through trees. Sam’s shirt sleeve is red with blood, but the bleeding seems to have stopped and Sam is greedily eating an apple. Annabelle and William ride near the front, conversing quietly. Annabelle is holding a compass, watching the nee sway. Todd moves his horse up next to them.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: We lost?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No. We got a couple more miles of this though, then we’ll reach a small stream, should be easy to cross. Then we stay on a road through a few fields and we should be at the place we’re staying by nightfall. After that, day and a half’s ride to Mexico. Todd is silent for a moment. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annabelle

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: Who runs this place we’re staying at tonight?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No one.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: No one?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: When I was staying at the Union hospital up near Chatsville, getting some metal bits pulled out of my arm by the most beautiful nurse in the world... (he looks at Annabelle, who ignores him) ...I was put next to this soldier, just a kid, really, had a gut wound somebody put there with a bayonet. We talked all the day, got to know each other pretty good, he was a right enough sort. Around the end, when he was starting to get pretty sick all the time... looks up at them.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: The bile in his guts spread.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yeah. That it did. Kid told me about this place he inherited down south, big ‘ol house, couple hundred acres, he got it from some great-uncle he never knew. He gave me pretty good directions to the place, he didn’t have no family or a girl or nothing, and said he wanted me to join up with him if he ever made it down there. Kid planned to get rich off farming. He wasn’t too bright. (shrugs) He died a couple of days after that.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: (almost to herself) His name was Jeffy. Jeffy Hollister. He was a good kid. He used to call me ‘Belle.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yeah, I remember that. (pause) (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: So, anyway, I guess you could say the place we’re headed to is mine. Or anyone’s who wants it, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: What if some folks moved in there?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: It’s in the middle of nowhere... I figure if we drop the name Jeffy Hollister whoever’s living there might show some hospitality. If they don’t, well, we’1l have to take care of them either way. It’s a place to stay. They ride in silence for a moment. The forest, overcast w trees, is growing darker.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: How’s your brother doing? William glances over at Sam.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: He’s fine for now. We’1ll get the bullet out when we reach the house, Annabelle can take care of that. After that, he should be good. The group is silent as they continue through the trees. Something moves in a thick bush as they move past, and Jo jumps, startled. A bird’s harsh, unidentifiable cry comes from the bush. Clyde laughs at Joseph.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Whoa, Joseph, stay on your horse there, big guy. Just a crow or something.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) You better shut up. Clyde smiles, but is silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is setting as the six make their way down a narro dirt road, corn fields on either side of them. The rows o corn cast the field in shadow, so that the road ahead is dark. At the front of the group, William and Annabelle speak quietly. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annabelle 11.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I think I killed a kid. Back in the town. Did you see it?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I thought I saw him fall. You sure that was you? Could’ve been anyone.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I think it was me.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I don’t know. (pause) Don’t tell the others. If they didn’t notice, they shouldn’t know. is silent for a moment, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: We almost there? William nods. Up ahead, ANNABELLE (CONT’D) We’re not lost, are we? I haven’t seen a house for awhile.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: They’re back there. It’s along this road, we just gotta go until we find it.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: It’s getting dark soon. Too many clouds for the moon to do us any good.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I know it. a clanking sound comes. The six immediately slow their horses, moving quietly. William’s

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: (speaking softly to Todd) What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: I don’t know. You got a lantern? eyes are narrowed and cold. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Don’t. Hold up a bit. The six ride forward in the dark, very slowly, reaching t top of a small hill. The noises from ahead are now more regular, and the sound of a horse’s footfall can be distinguished from a regular creaking sound. Further along the path, in the darkness ahead, a dim ligh becomes visible. The light sways back and forth slightly, moving towards them. The dog, Dog, looks up and growls slightly. Sam puts a hand on Dog to silence him.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (whispering) You see that? Annabelle draws out her pistol.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: Yeah. The group has grown silent, watching the bobbing light mo closer.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Will-o’-wisps.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: We ain’t near no swamp.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Ain’t unheard of.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: It looks like a lantern.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Sam?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Give us some light here.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Come on. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sam strikes a match on his thumbnail and holds it to a so caked lantern, lighting the wick. The lantern fizzles, th glows brightly, illuminating a large, black horse several yards in front of the group. They all jump.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Shit! The horse continues walking passively towards them. As it moves closer, the carriage that the horse is pulling beco visible. A lantern and several pots, pans and other unidentifiable objects hang from the roof of the carriage old man sits at the front, behind the horse, silent. William clears his throat and addresses the old man:

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Excuse me. The man does not respond. Joseph stirs on his horse, uneasily. William speaks louder. WILLIAM (CONT’D) Excuse me! The old man draws back on the horse’s reins. The horse gr softly and comes to a stop. The old man turns to face William, his eyes looking beyond him. The old man has no pupils; his eyes are pale blue, washed clean by glaucoma.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Who’s that?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I, uh... Say, we’re looking for the Hollister place. Is it far from here?

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Hollister? (shakes his head) Never heard of it. The old man turns away, lifting the horse’s reins.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (surprised) Are you sure? It’s a large farm, should be just up the road. Right after a creek.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: There’s no creek around here. Not for miles. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: (pause) Sorry I couldn’t help you. The old man lashes the reins and the horse starts forward again, easily pulling the carriage into motion. William a his group sit silently, pensive. As the carriage moves past them, Sam’s lantern reveals a standing inside the carriage, looking out at them through oblong window cut into the side of the carriage. The boy appears to be mentally disabled, and watches them complet without movement or expression. After a moment, the carriage is past the group, its lante light fading into the darkness of the road behind them. Todd spits tobacco juice into the cornfield as Joseph cou uneasily. Annabelle and Sam look at William, who kicks at side of his horse.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Well, come on, then. Annabelle and Sam immediately follow him. Todd, Joseph an Clyde exchange glances, then head after William, one by o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The road is getting narrower and increasingly covered wit tall grass, bent down in some areas but seemingly untouch in others. Annabelle and William can barely ride alongsid each other. Sam is riding in front of them, slowly, with running alongside Sam’s horse, visible in the lantern’s circle of light.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: I don’t like the looks of this.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: We’ve slept on grass before.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: We don’t even know where we are.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: We’ve got our compasses. (he nods over to his left) Mexico’s that way. Up ahead, Sam’s horse suddenly comes to a dead stop. Will and Annabelle tug on their horses’ reins quickly to avoid running into him, causing their horses to rear up slightl (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: (tense) What is it?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Well, look at this. Sam lifts up his lantern in front of him as the others cr around him, taking their horses into the field, which is suddenly thin and rocky. A creek, about fifteen feet wide bubbles in front of them, its waters black by the lantern light.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: Well, what the hell.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (to Dog) C’mere, girl. Sam lifts Dog up into his saddlebag, then rides out into creek. The water, though moving at a good speed, is only about a foot and a half deep. William nudges his horse forward, into the water, looking down.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Shit. Crazy old man. William begins riding forward, across the creek.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on! It shouldn’t be far from here. The rest of the group follow him forward, along the trail

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trail forks up ahead. Perhaps there was a path to the house once, but if so, the path was long ago consumed by thick corn fields that surround the house on all sides. I front of the house, the yard is so crowded with tall gras and weeds that it appears to be a field itself. The house sits on the horizon, just visible by the final orange rays of the sun. There is a stone well to the side the house, and clotheslines hang at angles just beyond th well. Behind the house is a tall barn, almost as big as t house itself. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: William, Annabelle and Sam are the first to see the house and they stand in the road, waiting for the other three t catch up. The house, a dark silhouette by the sun setting behind it, presents something of an ominous sight. Willia wets his lips with his tongue.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Well. Looks like a nice place. Sam climbs off his horse, holding its reins. The horse sh away, and Sam pets it, hushing it. Annabelle and William climb off their horses. Annabelle watches the house carefully. In one of the wind of the house, a previously indistinguishable shape sudden shifts and disappears from the window. Annabelle, seeing this, involuntarily takes a step back.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: I...
dialogues.text: (considers) I saw something in one of the windows.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I’m sure there was something in one of the windows. That whole place has got to be filled with all kinds of critters. Probably saw a bird or something.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (to Annabelle) Something, or someone?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: Someone. Like they was watching us. William looks at the house, as Clyde, Todd and Joseph rid behind them.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: We'll be careful. William steps out into the cornfield, pushing the stalks apart with one hand, holding his horse’s reins with the other. Suddenly, a creature with glowing eyes leaps out at Willi from the field, squealing. The creature is about the size a large raccoon. William shouts and spins to the side as creature runs past him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Just as it passes William, the creature is knocked onto i back by a gunshot. Sam holds a smoking gun, frowning down the creature. Dog begins growling.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ...

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: What the hell is that? The creature has soft white fur on its stomach, but has a like snout, long claws, and a bald, pink tail. The hair o its back is thick and bristled. The creature shakes for a moment, bleeding from its back, its legs pivoting, then i still. Dog quiets down.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: It looks like some kind of giant rat.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: Yeah, right. Did you see its eyes?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: How do you think I knew where to shoot at? Annabelle softly walks over to the creature and kicks its side, barely. The creature is still. SAM (CONT’D) (to William) You all right? William stiffens slightly, regaining his composure.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yeah. I’m fine. That thing gave me a start, that’s all.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: It ain’t breathing.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Well, that’s good news. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Kinda looks like a porcupine. Or a pig.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: Built almost like a baby bear, a little. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Maybe a porcupine and a muskrat had a kid. Clyde looks at Joseph quickly, to see if he is kidding.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Yeah, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Well, let’s get going. William steps back towards the cornfield. Everyone looks him, hesitantly. Williams moves towards the cornfield, th when no one follows, turns back sardonically towards the group. WILLIAM (CONT’D) Hey, Sam?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Keep your eyes out for more of those things, alright? William turns and walks into the cornfield. Sam follows, Todd, then Annabelle and the rest, leading their horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The six work their way through the dark cornfield, pushin unruly stalks to the side. Sam, Joseph and Todd each hold lanterns, which do little good in the dense cornfield exc to create alarming shadows. The horses make nervous sound every now and then, but continue forward. Suddenly Annabelle, up ahead, gives a sharp cry. Joseph, and Clyde rush forward towards the sound of her voice. Annabelle is standing, one hand on her chest, in front of scarecrow. The scarecrow’s limbs are tied to a wooden cro with barbed wire. A canvas sack, filled with peculiar lum and shadows, forms the scarecrow’s head. Joseph looks up it.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (annoyed) Oh, what the hell... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: That thing scared the life out of me. I thought it was a man.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: It’s creepy, alright. Todd and Clyde stare up at the scarecrow skeptically. Dog stands next to him. Joseph sniffs the air.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: What smells funny?

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: (to Annabelle) You want us to take it down?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: No! Don’t touch it! I mean, there’s no point. Let’s not bother. It just gave me a start, that’s all.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: All right. William coughs and spits.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Yes, it’s a very frightening scarecrow. If I were a crow, I’d go elsewhere. Since I’m not, anyone else want to get a move on? Annabelle looks down, embarrassed. William rolls his eyes her and the group moves past the scarecrow. Dog and Josep give it a wide berth and the horses make nervous noises a they pass.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What direction is the house in? Hey, Joseph, can you see the house?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Not over this corn. Want me to climb up on my horse?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: William, you know what direction we’re headed in? William looks back at him, then points ahead, to the left (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: The house is that way.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You sure? I would’ve thought we’d be there by now.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Cornfields always look smaller before you’re fighting your way through them.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I guess that’s about right. They work their way through the field. One of the horses whinnies. SAM (CONT’D) Damn, it’s quiet.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: I know. Clyde is in the lead, gruffly shoving his way through the cornstalks. He suddenly stumbles out of the cornfield and finds himself facing the house. The house is worn, its boards bleached by exposure to the elements. The windows are dark. The front door leans open

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Well, hell. The others stumble up behind Clyde.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Well, there it is.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Yeah. William looks around. Nobody is moving.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Come on, then. William walks over to a twisted oak tree, leaning several feet in front of the house, and ties his horse to a hangi branch. William’s horse shuffles slightly, rolling its ey William consoles it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shhh, girl. We’1l get you some water ina bit.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: The horses are acting weird.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Of course they are. They’re horses. They’re stupid and crazy.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: Huh. Well, someone should rub them down later, if they’re gonna be any good tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: I’1l1 do it, I don’t mind. The rest of the group tie their horses to the tree. Willi moves over, towards the house; the others follow. Sam tak step forward, then quickly steps back, looking at the gro

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Hell...

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I just stepped on a bird. A dead, slightly decayed bird rests on the ground. Sam examines the sole of his boot. SAM (CONT’D) That’s a first. Sam looks around. Another dead bird rests on the ground, few feet away. Dog sniffs at it. SAM (CONT’D) Look, there’s another one! Annabelle is clearly not very interested in this.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: Huh.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: There must be, like, cats around here or something. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Come on. I want to get that bullet out of you before an infection can start spreading.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Sure thing. (to Dog) Come on, Dog! Sam follows Annabelle up towards the house. Dog, after a moment, trots after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William steps up onto the wooden porch. As Joseph steps u next to him, the boards beneath them creak ominously. Jos and William look at each other, then William takes Joseph lantern and steps into the house. Todd looks back at the horses, tied to the oak tree. The horses are silent. Todd moves up onto the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William’s lantern illuminates the front room of the house wooden table sits over in a corner of the room, surrounde several chairs. A thick layer of dust covers nearly everything. Joseph begins to step forward into the room, but William a hand across Joseph’s chest, stopping him. Joseph looks William, questioningly. William points the lantern down at the floor. Two pairs o footprints are imprinted in the dust on the wooden floor, large boot prints. The boot prints lead off into the dark of the house. Clyde and Todd have moved in behind William and Joseph.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: What’s going on? Clyde sees the footprints on the floor and is quiet.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: It’s probably just some tramps. I’d settle here, if I was them. Let’s look around and find ‘em. William looks at Todd. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: TODD (CONT’D) There’s only two of them.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (nods) Alright. But everyone be careful. They move into the house, followed by Sam and Annabelle. trots in with them, looking around. Dog’s ears are up. Joseph immediately crosses over to the wooden table and d the four bags. The table creaks. One of the bags comes op slightly, and a few gold coins spill out onto the table. Joseph looks at the gold, then picks a coin up and bites He examines his tooth marks in the gold.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t chew on the gold, Joseph. Joseph quickly puts the coin back down on the table. Will addresses the group:

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s split up into pairs, search this floor and the upstairs. And the cellar, if this place has one.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: They might be out in that old barn. That looked big enough.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: We’1l check that after we finish with the house. William steps further into the house, shining his lantern around. A kitchen area, with a coal stove, is barely visi through a doorway; the corners of the kitchen are dark.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: I want to get to work on Sam’s shoulder right away.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yeah. That’s a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: It’s fine. It can wait.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, little brother? Bullets just bounce off you now, huh? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sam grins at William.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Clyde and Joseph, you guys take the upstairs. Todd and I will check this floor. Clyde and Joseph nod and walk off. William looks over at who is staring around the room.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, you want to come with us? Sniff something out? Dog looks at William, then slinks under a chair and curls

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s thing’s goddamn useless, Sam. Alright, then. William and Todd begin moving away.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: (to William) Be careful.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You too. Sam, keep a hand on your gun. I don’t want anybody sneaking up on us tramps or no.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Don’t worry about that.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I’m sure they’ve seen our lanterns by now, so they might come looking for us.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Maybe we scared them off.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: If they’ve been staying here? Not likely. William and Todd walk into the kitchen. Annabelle sets he lantern down on the table, turning it up, so that the roo grows brighter. She beckons Sam over to a chair; he sits. Annabelle begins fiddling through a satchel, pulling out tools, as Sam unbuttons and peels off his shirt. He wince his shoulder stretches. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: Leave it on, we’ll just move it aside. Annabelle pushes Sam’s shirt open, over his shoulders, exposing his torso. The bullet wound in Sam’s shoulder is very dark, almost black, and moist with purple blood. A large, bluish welt surrounds the wound. Annabelle winces she sees the wound. ANNABELLE (CONT’D) Jesus. Annabelle gently presses on the swollen area of flesh tha surrounds the bullet hole. Dark blood, almost black, well out of the scabby wound and crawls down Sam’s chest. Sam, curious, peers down, trying to see his own shoulder

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yeah, that doesn’t look too good, does it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William and Todd look around the kitchen. Todd opens the stove and sifts the ashes inside.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: This hasn’t been used anytime soon.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Huh. William is looking at the counter, where a dirty, cloth d lies, its limbs askew. One of the doll’s button eyes is missing.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: Let’s keep moving.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clyde and Joseph cautiously make their way up the stairs Joseph in the lead.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: This is a pretty nice place. Real fancy. Guy who built it must have been rich. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They reach the top of the stairwell and find themselves i short hallway, with three doors, one in front of them, th other two at opposite ends of the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Think those guys are up here?

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Maybe. Don’t worry, they’1l take one look at you and wet themselves, big guy.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: I could crush them.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: I know it. Here, you go check that room down there, and I’1l check this one.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Okay. INT. CHILDREN’S BEDROOM - EVENING Joseph moves down the hallway, away from Clyde. Joseph op the door at the end of the hall and walks slowly into the room. Joseph looks around the sparse bedroom. Two small beds re against one wall. There is a dresser in the room, and a closet. Joseph carefully walks into the room, checking behind the beds. Nothing is there. He moves over to the closet door, somewhat nervous. Joseph turns the doorknob slowly and opens the closet doo shining his lantern in. The closet has a few sets of children’s clothes, including a small dress. The hanging clothes cast dark shadows inside the closet. Joseph pushes the clothes apart, to determine that nothin behind them. He breathes a slight sigh of relief when he nothing but wall and walks back through the bedroom. Just as Joseph reaches the doorway to the bedroom, a slig scratching sound comes from within the room. Joseph stops turns around, holding the lantern out. He appears to be a in the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Is anyone there? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: There is no response. Joseph narrows his eyes, looking at beds. He crouches down to peer under them, but it is too to see under the beds from the door. Joseph rises to a standing position. A dark figure is standing behind him. Joseph starts and whirls around to face Clyde, who jumps back.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Shit!

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Oh, man... You scared me. Clyde pauses as they both catch their breath.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Yeah, this place makes me a little jumpy, too... Nothing in there?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Nah, nothing. Anything in yours?

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Just some weird clothes and stuff. Looks like it was a guest room or something that no one ever used, the bed’s still made. (pause) Let’s check the third room together.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Okay. Clyde and Joseph walk down the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William stands in a room, shining his lantern around. The room features a large, black piano, covered with dust. A plush chairs are lined against one wall. Stacks of sheet music are piled on a small table. Moving forward, William sees that a dirty picture frame i propped up against the side of the piano, its back facing outward. William reaches out and turns the picture frame over, directing his lantern light onto it. The picture on the front of the frame is of a man seated chair, with what appears to be two small boys and a very young girl standing around him, facing forward. The four figures are all clad in formal attire. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: It is a very traditional family portrait, but it does not seem to have been fully finished, giving the portrait an eerie quality; the facial features of the children are absent, as if the artist never got around to the details their likenesses, and the man’s facial expression looks inappropriately somber. William stares at the portrait, e narrowed, and the man’s image on the canvas gazes back ou him. William nervously looks behind him, into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Hey, Todd, get a look at this. There is no response. A creaking sound comes from the darkness just outside the doorway, then silence.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Todd?

dialogues.speaker: TODD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah? William reacts to Todd’s voice with visible relief.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: TODD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: There’s a door here, I’m trying to get it open. William moves forward, towards Todd’s voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William moves into a hallway, where Todd has his shoulder braced against a thick wooden door.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: This looks like it might go down toa fruit cellar or something, it’s in the right place for it.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You can’t get it open?

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: Nah, it’s like there’s something up against it. William places his lantern on the floor and moves to the door, next to Todd. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They brace themselves against the door and try to force i Open, straining against the door. The door bends but does give.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Hell. They stop trying. Todd stretches his back.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: It doesn’t feel like it’s locked or anything, though; the door gives near the handle.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yeah. We’1ll get Joseph back here, see if he can force it. Failing that, we’1ll chop it down. Wouldn’t want anyone to have barricaded themselves in there especially if we’re going to get any sleep tonight.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: Yeah. Todd puts his head against the door, listening, then taps it with his hand.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Come on, let’s get back and see how Sam’s doing.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annabelle pulls a small lump of metal out from Sam’s shoulder, using a pair of thin pliers. Sam grits his teet his eyes clenched shut.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: There. We’re done. Sam opens his eyes, relaxing slightly. Red blood flows fr his wound. He reaches forward, grabs a bottle of whiskey the table and drinks deeply from it. Sam stops drinking to gasp:

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Christ. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: Hopefully that’11 help matters.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You got anything to bandage it up with?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: Just a second. Annabelle takes the bottle of whiskey from him and takes quick drink. She then bends forward and pours whiskey ont his wound. Sam jerks away.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Shit! Ow! Annabelle takes another drink of whiskey, then passes the bottle back over to Sam, who stares at her resentfully.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: That’11 do. Annabelle pulls out some cotton bandages and begins lacin them over Sam’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You could’ve told me you were going to do that.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: Quit whining. Sam tenderly touches his shoulder, still wincing. His fac flushed and covered with sweat. Annabelle suddenly turns towards a window, which faces outside. ANNABELLE (CONT’D) Did you see that? Sam turns, following her gaze. The window is completely d

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: I thought I saw someone standing on the porch. (pause) It might have just been my reflection. Sam tightens his grip on his pistol, watching the window. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yeah? Both Annabelle and Sam look over at the front door, which slightly open. A breeze moves the front door open a few inches. Behind them, William and Todd walk into the room. William nods over to Sam.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: How you doing? Sam glances over at William, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Just splendid.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (to Annabelle) Were you able to get it out?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: Yeah. It’s weird... It wasn’t that deep.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: We should start lighting these lanterns around here. Todd indicates two lanterns, mounted on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yeah, good idea. Todd moves over and lights the two lanterns, which flare immediately to life.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: They’ve still got oil in them.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Good. The front door creaks open further. Everyone in the room looks at this nervously, and the lanterns flicker slightl

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fucking wind. Sam rises to his feet and crosses over to the door, holdi one hand over his bandage.  32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam steps out onto the porch and looks around. There is nothing on the porch. It is almost completely dark outsid and he can see very little. He squints into the darkness then turns and walks back into the front room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph and Clyde walk into the room from the kitchen at t same time as Sam, dimming their lanterns as they enter. C has something slung over his arm. Annabelle and William t to regard them.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Look what we found in a bedroom upstairs. He holds out the object. It is a gray Confederate army jacket. Everyone regards this silently. Sam sits back dow across Annabelle, a pensive expression on his face.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Deserters?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Maybe. Did you find anything else?

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Nothing important. This was hung over a bedpost.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: That changes matters.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: They might have just moved on.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Maybe. why would they leave their jacket?

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Probably ‘cause they found a better one. There’s plenty of clothes upstairs. If you’re a deserter, sometimes the best idea isn’t to go around in your army uniform. William nods.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Still, we should check out that barn now, just to be sure. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: I agree. Clyde pulls out a pistol and cocks it. He grins over at T CLYDE (CONT’D) You want to go hunting? Todd shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: It’s nothing to me.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Regardless of whether we find anything, we’1l sleep in shifts tonight. I know I’1ll sleep better knowing someone’s on watch. We’ll keep the lanterns on in this room so someone can stay up.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I’ll take the first shift. I’m not tired.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Okay. Dog, underneath the chair, begins edging forward, its hac rising. Dog is looking at an empty corner of the room. No notices Dog.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: This place isn’t exactly turning out to be the safe haven we hoped for.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I know it. We’1l move on at first light tomorrow. Dog begins growling at the empty corner of the room. Dog quickly looks over at the open front door of the house, t looks back at the corner, slowly backing away.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: What the hell? Dog continues growling and edging away from whatever has attention in the corner. William and Clyde move over to s at the corner of the room from Dog’s angle.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Do you see anything over there? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (to Dog) What the hell’s wrong with you? Dog does not acknowledge Sam. Suddenly Dog leaps back wit yelp, turns and runs out of the house. Sam rises to his f moving after Dog. SAM (CONT’D) Hey! Dog! Get back here! Sam steps forward, but clutches his shoulder, wincing. SAM (CONT’D) Damn... Annabelle moves over to Sam.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: You alright?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’m fine... I just got a little dizzy there. Let me sit down. Sam sits back in his chair. Clyde and William move outsid William turning up his lantern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The yard is completely dark. The lantern barely illuminat the cornstalks that surround the house. Clyde moves down porch steps, calling out:

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Dog! Hey, dog! Come here! Clyde claps his hands and whistles. The horses, nearby in front yard, stomp their feet anxiously, making noises. In cornfield, something rustles and moves the stalks. Willia and Clyde turn towards this sound.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: There he is.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Dog! Come on, boy! The rustling sound does not come again. A light breeze ge stirs the corn stalks around them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CLYDE (CONT’D) Maybe we should get some of that jerky, set it out for him. He’1l come back when he wants to, I reckon.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Setting out jerky will probably just get us possums.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Yeah. William kicks at the ground.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: We’ll do it anyway. Just in case.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Clyde and William head back towards the house. Todd and Joseph are in the doorway, watching.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: He’s not out there?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: He took off. He’1l be back. He’s run off like this before.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: Never like the hounds of hell were after him.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: That was damn weird, wasn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: He’s a dog. Dogs are weird. They walk inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William looks at Sam, who is still seated. Sam is playing with the gold coins.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You doing alright? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’m fine, I just got a little queasy. I must have lost more blood than I thought.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You still want first watch?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yeah. I might pass out, but I won’t be falling asleep. (pause) Just kidding. In the distance, thunder rumbles. They look up at the sou

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: That’s just great.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Hey, it ain’t bad. A good storm could get rid of any tracks we might have left.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: But if the ground gets muddy, we could leave tracks that’1l last for days. William smiles at Sam.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Hey, Sam? Cheer up. Thunder rumbles again.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah. Anyway, who’s going out to the barn?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph, Clyde, William and Annabelle step out of the back door of the house, facing the large barn. A stone well an outhouse are positioned near the side of the house. Betwe the house and the barn, two empty clotheslines hang betwe oak trees, swaying in the wind. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: I’1l be just a second. Annabelle walks towards the outhouse. William, Clyde and Joseph walk over to the barn. The large, double doors to the barn stand open; it is dar within. Clyde walks inside the barn, holding his lantern high. William and Joseph follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The barn is large, with a loft. The lanterns William, Cly and Joseph hold illuminate the tall walls. Beneath the lo are three rooms, divided by wooden walls. These rooms eac contain thin mattresses on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Slave quarters. Clyde looks up at the roof of the barn. CLYDE (CONT’D) The roof looks tight. I wouldn’t want to sleep in the hay up there, though. who knows what’s up there.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Let’s find out. William walks over to a tall ladder that leads up to the loft. Holding his lantern with one hand, he begins scalin the ladder.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Careful up there.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yeah. About halfway to the loft, the rung under William’s feet breaks with a dry snap. William grabs onto another rung w his free hand, but it is also rotten, and comes off in hi hand. William falls to the ground, about six feet, landing on h back. His lantern hits the ground next to him, shattering spilling flaming oil onto the ground. William rolls away. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Shit. Clyde begins attempting to kick dirt onto the flaming poo oil, to no avail.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Hold on! Joseph runs away, as William sits up, coughing. A moment later, Joseph runs into the barn again, carrying a bucket water. He throws the water onto the fire, dousing it. William rises to his feet, brushing himself off.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Damn.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: You alright?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yeah. Well, forget that. Whatever’s up there isn’t getting down, anyway. Goddamnit. William kicks the ladder, breaking another rung. Behind h Joseph wanders off, towards a corner of the barn. Lightning flashes, filling the barn with pale light, abru casting strange shadows across the barn. The large shadow a figure looms over the shadows of William and Clyde. They jump and whirl around, to face Annabelle. Clyde grab his chest.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Hell. This place is turning me into a little girl.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Let’s go back inside.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: We should put the horses in here. Before the storm really spooks them.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yeah. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: William moves ahead of them, towards the house. Annabelle looks at Clyde.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: William broke the ladder. Over in the corner, Joseph is kicking at a pile of straw. bends down and extracts an object from the straw.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Hey! William looks over at Joseph, who holds the object out. I a worn, damaged book, which appears to be bound in dark leather.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I thought I saw something in there. It looks like a bible. Joseph flips through the book, then shuts it. Joseph hand the book to William, then examines one of his fingers and begins sucking on it. JOSEPH (CONT’D) Damn.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Paper cut. (indicates the book) What’s it say? William flips through the pages of the book. There are no images, just page after page of indecipherable writing in dark ink. The writing appears to be Arabic.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Joseph looks at William suspiciously. William holds the b up, pages out.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s not in English, Joseph.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: Let me see that. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: William hands the book to her. Annabelle flips through it frowning. ANNABELLE (CONT’D) Weird. Is this a code?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: How should I know?

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: I wonder who left it here.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Come on, let’s get out of here before that storm comes any closer. You can play with the book inside. Joseph picks up the bucket and they exit the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As William, Clyde, and Annabelle walk back into the house Joseph moves over to the well and ties the bucket back to rope, which hangs over a bar above the well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Todd and Sam are both drinking from the bottle of whiskey counting gold pieces at the table. Clyde nods at them as William, Annabelle and Joseph walk into the room from the porch. Annabelle sets the book down on the table, next to gold.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: (to Todd) That’s not all the whiskey we have, is it?

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: I got two more bottles.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Pass that here. Sam passes Clyde the bottle. Clyde drinks and passes it t William, who drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annabelle and William stand in the hallway, close to each other. Behind them, Todd, Sam, Clyde and Joseph are playi cards at the table, two half-empty bottles in front of th (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: They said there were some beds upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You want to lie down for a little while?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: Or something. They kiss, lightly, then Annabelle pulls away from Willia He leans towards her and they kiss again, longer.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Sounds good. William and Annabelle surreptitiously exit the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annabelle and William are entangled on a large bed, makin love by the light of a candle mounted on a thick, wooden dresser. Annabelle is on top of William. The flickering candle flame casts strange shadows over her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph throws down his cards and stretches. Sam, Clyde an Todd continue covertly staring at their cards. Sam is sweating and pale.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: That’s it. I’m out.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: Wise decision. Wiser than our friends here, who are going to lose their share before they even get to count it. Clyde chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: You'd be better at bluffing, Todd, if you’d play it down a little. I’1l see you, and I’1ll raise you five more. Todd whistles slowly, shaking his head. Sam frowns. Outsi lightning flashes, illuminating the horses. One of the ho rears up with a snort.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Aw, hell, I should get those horses into the barn before this storm gets any closer. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Joseph rises to his feet. Clyde looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: You need any help?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: ‘Kay. Clyde returns his attention to the cards. Joseph steps outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph leads three horses through the backyard, into the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph ties the three horses next to the other three hors The horses seem somewhat calmer in the barn. One of them leans down to chew on some hay.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: There you go. I’1l go and get you some water, how’s that? Joseph pats one of the horses and exits the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph walks up to the well, holding onto the bucket and with one hand. At the bottom of the well, a slight splash sound is audible, followed immediately by a small voice, of a child’s.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BOY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Please... Please help me... Joseph freezes, then leans over to look into the well, st holding the bucket. The well is completely dark; nothing visible inside.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Hello? The voice comes again, as if from the bottom of the well.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BOY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Please help me! Help me out of here! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: (confused) Are you in the water down there?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BOY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes. Help me!

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BOY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Please, help me! My daddy threw me in here, mister. The water’s too deep!

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: (to himself) My god. Joseph looks around, as if looking for help, then calls d into the well.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hang on just a second, kid. I’m lowering a bucket down, okay? No sound comes from the bottom of the well. JOSEPH (CONT’D) Okay?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BOY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Please hurry! It’s cold. Joseph quickly begins lowering the bucket.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Okay. Don’t worry, I’11 pull you up out of there in just a moment (to himself, angry) Then we’1l talk about what the hell’s going on here. The rope goes slack in Joseph’s hands.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can you see the bucket? It’s down there. (pause) Have you got it? The rope is pulled taut again. Joseph grips it with one h

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BOY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes. I’ve got it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Okay. Now just hold on to that bucket, alright? Joseph begins pulling the bucket up, dragging up the rope hand over hand. The child clearly weighs more than Joseph expected, and he grits his teeth as he pulls. JOSEPH (CONT’D) (to himself) Jesus. Joseph begins dragging the bucket back up, straining agai the rope.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (calling out) How are you doing? There is no response from the well. Joseph continues pull the bucket up. JOSEPH (CONT’D) Almost there... Joseph reaches forward into the darkness of the well, to hold of the rope, and a child’s small hand reaches out fr the darkness, grabbing onto Joseph’s wrist. Joseph’s eyes widen in surprise. Quickly, Joseph is yanked off his feet, down into the wel The bucket moves with him, the rope twisting after it. Th is a large splashing sound, then silence from within the well. The wind tosses the grass around the well. Lightning flas

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clyde reacts to the lightning, looking around. Sam and To are still playing cards.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: I wonder what’s taking Joseph? Todd shrugs, then looks at Sam curiously.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: Hey, Sam, you okay there? Sam is rubbing at his collarbone. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I don’t know. This wound’s kind of itching.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: That means it’s healing.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yeah. (pause) What the hell is taking Joseph? Todd looks up. The three exchange glances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Todd, Sam and Clyde walk out into the backyard, holding g looking around.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Hey, Joseph! You out here? The wind tosses the branches of a nearby oak tree. Sam sc up at this.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: I’1l check the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William and Annabelle lie in bed together, naked under th covers. Annabelle is asleep in William’s arms. A slight creaking sound comes from outside the bedroom, followed by a soft knock on the door. William opens one e The soft knocking comes again, followed by a whisper:

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey, William! William grimaces, then carefully extricates himself from Annabelle’s arms. Annabelle moans in her sleep and rolls over. William quickly slips his pants on and walks to the bedroom door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William steps out of the bedroom. Sam is standing there, looking anxious. Sam’s face is pale.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: What is it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Joseph disappeared.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: He’s gone. He went out to take the horses to the barn and he never came back. We all just went around looking for him.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Nothing?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Any tracks?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: None that I could see. William frowns for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Okay. Let me get my clothes on, then I'll be right out. Sam nods. William goes back into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William quickly buttons his shirt next to the bed, his bo already on. He then leans down and gently shakes Annabell arm.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Hey. Hey, honey. Annabelle opens her eyes, looking tired.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: Mmm?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Joseph wandered off somewhere. I’m gonna go look for him.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: Joseph’s gone? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yeah, the boys can’t find him. I’11 go see what’s up, you stay here.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: Okay. (she yawns) Maybe he went off looking for Dog.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Could be. You wanna get up and do me a favor, though? Annabelle smiles up at him.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Lock the door to this room after I step out. Just in case.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: I’ve got my gun. William leans down and kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I know, but I want you to get some sleep.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: Uh. Okay. Annabelle stretches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William exits the bedroom, shutting the door behind him. Immediately the sound of a latch turning and locking is heard. William heads off down the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William and Sam walk off the porch, into the front yard. gestures to the rear of the house.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Clyde and Todd are back there. William walks off quickly, towards the rear of the house. stands in the front yard for a moment. He rubs softly at shoulder, wincing. The fabric of Sam’s shirt is dark and in a small circle just over his bandage. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Something falls to the ground directly in front of Sam, hitting the ground hard. Sam looks up at the empty sky ab him, then holds out his lantern and steps forward. A medium-sized bird is curled up in the grass, having jus fallen from the sky. The bird’s eyes are closed and it is moving. Sam looks at the bird, then looks back up at the Lightning flashes, followed immediately by thunder. A dog’s bark comes from the cornfield, nearby. Sam jumps turns to face the sound. SAM (CONT’D) Dog? Sam steps forward, then stops, slowly moving his arm, wiggling his fingers. SAM (CONT’D) Ow. Damn. Sam walks through the yard and steps into the cornfield, lightly moving in between the haphazard rows, making his through the stalks. Sam is following the trail the six of them made with their horses when they first moved through field, trampling down a wide path of corn. Sam moves towa the path, alert. Sam’s lantern is not doing much good in the field illuminating only the stalks around him, all of which are near enough to touch. Sam stops and slaps his leg. SAM (CONT’D) Dog! Come’ere, boy! Sam continues making his way through the cornfield, looki around. He whistles for Dog, clapping his hands. A moment later, Dog’s bark comes again, further ahead in the cornfield, to Sam’s right. SAM (CONT’D) Come on, boy! What the hell are you doing out here? Sam pushes his way through the cornstalks to his side, mo more quickly now, sweating. Dog barks again; again, Sam h towards the noise, pushing through the stalks. SAM (CONT’D) Dog! Hold up, there! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Sam stumbles into a clearing. Briefly disoriented, Sam raises his lantern. Directly in front of him is the wooden cross where the scarecrow was hung. Strands of barbed wire are still attached to the cr but the scarecrow is gone. Sam backs away, then looks around. SAM (CONT’D) (to himself) Where the hell... The cornfield is still, except for the wind lightly movin the stalks. SAM (CONT’D) Dog? There is no response. Sam slowly begins backing away from cross, then turns and moves back into the cornfield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William, Todd and Clyde are standing near the well, looki dejected, as Sam quickly walks up to them, still covered a thin sheen of sweat.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Well, could he have just wandered off for a little while? Maybe he’s pulling a joke or something.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: I sure hope so. I’d hate to think of anything that could take Joseph without making enough noise for us to hear. Clyde cups his hands and shouts into the wind:

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Joseph! There is no response. After a moment, William shrugs and four men walk back towards the house.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I think we’d better each hold onto our guns from now on, though, particularly if we go out alone.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I’m way ahead of you there. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Where’ve you been?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I think... Nevermind. (shakes head) I heard Dog in the cornfield and I went after him. I guess I got a little lost turned out I wasn’t headed in the direction I thought I was. Got turned around.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You’re lucky you made it out of there. You can’t see where you’re going in that field in the daytime, much less at night with a storm coming. Whoever tended that field’s long gone. Clyde falls back a little from the group as they walk thr the yard.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: I gotta take care of something, I’1l be around in a minute. Clyde walks towards the outhouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William, Sam and Todd sit in the living room. William thr a knife at the wall; the knife plunges into the wood. Wil rises to his feet, crosses over to the knife and takes it of the wall. He then walks back to his chair and throws h knife at the wall again.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You should get some sleep.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Not likely. Todd picks up a handful of gold coins and begins stacking them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annabelle lies in bed, breathing softly. In the bedroom, closet door slowly creaks open. Annabelle opens her eyes; the room is silent. Annabelle frowns, then blinks and shuts her eyes again. The sound o quick footsteps moving across the room is heard. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Annabelle opens her eyes wide and sits up in bed, looking around the dark room. Her hand goes over to her pistol on pillow next to her. Annabelle lifts the pistol and pulls the hammer. Seeing nothing in the room, Annabelle shifts slightly, still craning her head around. She then leans b and blows her hair out of her face.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: (to herself) You’re dreaming, honey. Annabelle stretches, then looks around the room again. Sighing, she climbs out of bed and cautiously crosses ove the closet. Annabelle gingerly pushes some clothes out of way and looks inside; the closet contains only clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clyde sits in the outhouse, looking straight ahead, passively. He is chewing on a piece of hay. Just outside of the outhouse, a rustling sound is audible like something moving through the tall grass. Clyde straightens, reaching down for his shotgun. The rustling sound comes closer to the outhouse. Then a sniffing noise, like that of an animal, comes near the bo of the outhouse door. Clyde relaxes slightly, though he i still tense. He lowers the shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Hey. Dog? The sniffing at the bottom of the door stops. There is silence for a moment, then the sound of claws raking agai the bottom of the door. Clyde jerks back. The clawing sound continues, with a quiet, animalistic grunting noise. Clyde stands, hitching up his pants, and points the shotgun at the door. CLYDE (CONT’D) (whispering) Fucking hell? Clyde moves to the door as the clawing continues and, ina swift movement, throws the door open and lowers the shotg There is nothing outside of the door. Clyde steps quickly of the outhouse and looks around; no creature is in sight CLYDE (CONT’D) Dog? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Clyde stands for a moment, looking confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annabelle shuts the closet door, then turns around and surveys the room. She looks at the bed. After a moment, Annabelle crosses over to the bed, kneels down on the flo and peers under the bed. Under the bed, in the opposite corner, something large is just visible in the shadows. Annabelle cannot make out it features; it could be crouching animal, or a pile of clothing. Very slowly, Annabelle reaches for the lantern to the bed and holds the lantern out at floor level. Illuminated under the opposite corner of the bed is a sma boy, crouched in a fetal position, silently rocking back forth. Annabelle frowns, peering closer. Just then, the b lifts his head up and looks straight at her, his face dar Moving with unnatural speed under the bed, the boy crawls towards Annabelle, scuttling like a crab. He is immediate face to face with her. The boy grins at Annabelle in the light of the lantern; h toothless and his eyes are completely black, with no iris Annabelle screams and falls back away from the boy, knock over the lantern. It goes out, plunging the room into complete darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annabelle’s scream is audible from upstairs. William, Sam Todd react, then run out of the room for the stairs, Will in the lead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annabelle is standing in the corner of the room, facing t open bedroom door. William runs into the doorway, Todd an Sam coming up behind him.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: What? What is it?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: There was a boy in here!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Where is he? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: He ran out. Annabelle points towards them, in the doorway. William lo at Sam and Todd, who look at each other and head for the opposite rooms. William crosses over to Annabelle. He puts an arm around

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You alright, honey?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: Yeah... I’m fine. He just scared me... The lighting or something.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: This a young kid?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. He couldn’t be too old. He was small. His face...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Well, they’1l find him in a second. Todd and Sam appear in the doorway again. Todd shakes his head. WILLIAM (CONT’D) What?

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: We’re the only ones on this floor. He’s not here. William stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Well, could he have gone out of a window? Todd shrugs. Sam walks into the bedroom, looking sick, an sits down heavily on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: He couldn’t have gone downstairs, we would’ve passed him.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: I don’t know. A lot of these big houses have passageways. William and Annabelle both look around the walls, nervous (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I sure hate the thought of that. We should start checking around, see if any of these walls are hollow. Annabelle is watching Sam.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: You okay, Sam?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yeah. I’m just feeling a little tired.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: You should lie down and get some rest. I know I’m not going to be sleeping for awhile.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, we’ll see about that. One way or another, we’re moving on at first light tomorrow, and we all need to get some sleep before then. Sam, you go ahead, we’1ll wake you if anything comes up. Sam nods and stiffly lies back on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
