dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dog’s hackles are up and Dog’s teeth are bared. Dog snarl William, saliva dripping from its mouth.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (softly) Dog? Dog growls again, eyes fixed on William’s. All the hairs Dog’s back are sticking up straight. William slowly reaches into his coat, for his gun. His gu not there. William realizes this, then slowly looks for h gun. William’s gun is about a yard in front of him. The g is between William and Dog. William carefully begins edging forward, toward the gun. growls again, crouching down. William comes to a stop, th when Dog does not move, begins moving towards the gun aga Dog lunges forward at William, snarling. William raises h arm to block Dog and Dog’s teeth clamp down on William’s forearm. William yells. The weight of Dog knocks William to the ground. William flails against Dog, trying to pull his bloody arm out of Dog’s mouth. The dog thrashes its head wildly, mangling William’s arm. William screams. William rolls over onto Dog, yanking his arm out of Dog’s teeth. A chunk of William’s arm is left in Dog’s jaw. Dog immediately twists away from William’s grasp and bites on William’s upper leg, tearing at William’s flesh. William yells again, then lifts his other leg up and kick Dog in the head. The blow knocks Dog back, away from Will towards William’s gun. The dog scrambles, regaining its balance. William immediately rises to his feet. He sees that Dog i nearer to the gun than him, then turns and runs. Limping badly, William stumbles forward through the cornfield, in general direction of the trail. Dog is immediately after William, running quickly through cornfield. The fur on the front of Dog’s body is slick wi William’s blood. William runs as fast as he can, plowing through the cornstalks. He looks behind himself and can see Dog rushi up just behind him, growling. William plunges forward. Wounded, William cannot possibly outrun Dog, and Dog is gaining fast. Dog is within ten feet of William’s heels a William stumbles forward. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dog comes closer, snapping at William’s ankles. Then Dog suddenly comes to a stop, staring straight ahead. William continues desperately running forward, oblivious the fact that Dog is no longer directly behind him. Suddenly, William bursts out of the cornfield, into the light. Blinded, William squints, trying to shield his eye from the sun. A gunshot booms from directly in front of h William’s chest explodes. He falls back into the cornfiel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of ten Confederate soldiers stand on the trail, looking at something on the ground. Half of them are perc on top of horses; the others hold the horses’ reins. One JOHNSTON, is holding a smoking rifle. He looks down at th object on the ground with evident revulsion.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNSTON
dialogues.text: What the hell is that? One of the men shakes his head, moving closer. On the ground, with half of its body inside the field, li medium-sized furry creature. It is dead, a wide, blood-so bullet wound gaping in the soft white fur of its chest. T creature has a face like a furry pig’s; it is the same ty of creature that Sam shot. A confederate soldier with a thick mustache leans forward spits, then squints up at the house in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: MUSTACHED SOLDIER
dialogues.text: That’s the damned ugliest thing I’ve ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNSTON
dialogues.text: (laughs nervously) That thing sure jumped out at us, didn’t it? Gave me a scare. One of the men on a horse, wearing a more elaborate unifo clears his throat. This is the CAPTAIN.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Well, unless you’re fixing to eat it leave it alone. Johnston and Kormer, you two go check out that house and barn. I’m sure they’ve moved on if they came this way, but just make sure nothing’s there. The place looks abandoned and it wouldn’t have been a bad spot to spend the night. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Johnston and another, red-haired man step away from the group, towards the cornfield. CAPTAIN (CONT’D) The rest of us will continue. You two water your horses and give them some grain; see what you can find. You can catch up with us later in the day. Johnston and Kormer nod, pulling their horses with them. The captain and the seven other soldiers continue down th trail. Leading their horses, Johnston and Kormer step int the cornfield and begin working their way through the tal stalks, towards the house. A light breeze sways the cornstalks that surround them.
